channel.title: Laptop car adaptor
channel.description:
I wanna plug my laptop into the fag socket in my car so I can use it for more than the two hours battery life. My laptop is a Dell Inspiron | 6400. I looked on the Dell website and as I expected, found some proprietary adapter for over £50. I then went to play.com and as I expected, found one for £15 but was unsure if it would be compatible: http://www.play.com/PC/PCs/4-/3479826/Trust-Notebook-Car-Adapter/Product.html
* Power adapter designed for travellers to power or charge your notebook from a cigarette lighter socket * Equipped with different connectors and selectable power output to assure compatibility with most notebook models * 10 letter coded swappable connectors * Switchable 15/16/18/19/20 Volt (3.5 A) and 22/24 Volt (2.9 A) DC output
How would I know if this will work with my laptop, or the connectors will even fit into mine? My current power supply says 19.5V, 3.34A so I did some calculations for the power supply and they don't really add up.. 18.0V - 3.50A - 63.00W 19.0V - 3.50A - 66.50W [b]19.5V - 3.34A - 65.13W[/b] MINE 20.0V - 3.50A - 70.00W Is 1.13 Watts of difference fine? Does the slight difference in potential difference and current matter? This is really important and I need it within the next week so I'm buying from play.com or somewhere trustworthy so they don't mess around.

item.title: Laptop car adaptor
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

I’ve ordered what Mopman suggested, thanks folks.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Andrew wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:8, topic:291300”][quote author=Andrew link=topic=384986.msg2889469#msg2889469 date=1248809516]
The converters work fine, but be prepared to buy a new one every few months.
[/quote]
Or a new fuse for the car.[/quote]

mhm

item.title: Laptop car adaptor
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

Moparisthebest:

The watts need to be as close as possible (should be the same), but you can have more amps than your laptop needs, it just probably won’t run with less amps. Understand?

It should be okay then because the amperage of all the connectors in this is 3.5A… but still, the voltage is 0.5V lower and the power is just over 1 watt too high. Are these differences critical? I don’t want to go burning out my laptop or anything stupid just so I can use it in the car.

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:5, topic:291300”]you can get a 12 -> 230V converter for your car
then you can plug anything into the “fag*” socket.

*I wonder if any retarded fag has shoved their cocks into one of these before?[/quote]

If I don’t find a specific laptop transformer I’ll go for one of those, the main reason being that it seems inefficient to convert 12V->230V->9V and no doubt having some weird frequency and also providing the car with extra heating.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop car adaptor
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:2, topic:291300”]http://www.amazon.co.uk/power-socket-240v-plug-Inverter/dp/B000ORW8RC/ref=pd_cp_ce_1

not sure how good an inverter that is, i imagine the more you spend the happier youll be with it[/quote]

I thought of a universal adaptor like that… but I remember seeing them in argos ages ago for like £60 so it can’t be great for £15. I think a direct car>laptop converter would be better, and I’m unlikely to want to power anything else in the car.

I’d also be happier if that was on play.com I’ve never used amazon before… how are they with delivery?

btw here’s a sexy pic of my charger: http://www.tjl.co.uk/bmz_cache/a/a89ebb64d9143a3c7e38eee12fb18349.image.469x550.jpg

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop car adaptor
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

I wanna plug my laptop into the fag socket in my car so I can use it for more than the two hours battery life. My laptop is a Dell Inspiron | 6400. I looked on the Dell website and as I expected, found some proprietary adapter for over £50. I then went to play.com and as I expected, found one for £15 but was unsure if it would be compatible:

http://www.play.com/PC/PCs/4-/3479826/Trust-Notebook-Car-Adapter/Product.html

* Power adapter designed for travellers to power or charge your notebook from a cigarette lighter socket * Equipped with different connectors and selectable power output to assure compatibility with most notebook models * 10 letter coded swappable connectors * Switchable 15/16/18/19/20 Volt (3.5 A) and 22/24 Volt (2.9 A) DC output

How would I know if this will work with my laptop, or the connectors will even fit into mine?

My current power supply says 19.5V, 3.34A so I did some calculations for the power supply and they don’t really add up…

18.0V - 3.50A - 63.00W
19.0V - 3.50A - 66.50W
19.5V - 3.34A - 65.13W MINE
20.0V - 3.50A - 70.00W

Is 1.13 Watts of difference fine? Does the slight difference in potential difference and current matter?

This is really important and I need it within the next week so I’m buying from play.com or somewhere trustworthy so they don’t mess around.
